My problem is I know someone who is absolutely awful in league. They went heavily negative every single game in ranked, but got carried by a good team. They managed to get to sliver during their promos.
Meanwhile, I decide to try my promos, and get at least one afk or troll *on my team* every game. I ended in bronze II.

I'm not saying i don't belong in bronze (I believe i do),  but luck is a big factor in ranked.

It's my belief that luck plays a fairly strong factor in *how quickly* you gain rank, but not in whether you're *capable* of gaining rank.

If you're in bronze, but play on a gold level, poor luck may keep you from flying out of bronze, but it won't *prevent* you from getting to silver+. Just slow you down.

This works the other way as well: If you play on a bronze level, but through stupidly good luck get placed in gold, that good luck may keep you from plummeting back down to bronze, but it won't *prevent* your decline.

Or, to put it another way: In the long run, luck becomes statistically irrelevant. In the short run, it causes weirdness.

The problem is, where do you draw the line of "you're now where you belong"? What if it takes roughly 6 years to properly even out the 8/10 times getting a leaver/afker to get you where you belong, but nobody knows that.. 3 years down the road everyones telling this silver he belongs there when in reality he belongs in high gold or better? 

How about those very good players who, just get horrendous teams all the time but don't have the time to sink hundreds of hours a week into league? They'll realistically never get close to seeing the rank they deserve. 

Obviously the above with the 6yrs is an inflated example, but the point remains. Not everyone gets the same amount of afkers/trolls. Not everyone can carry, but just because you can carry doesn't mean you're a good player either (this is actually true, as just being able to gobble up a crap ton of cs and run everyone through with an OP champ doesn't mean you're good when it comes to real things that matter such as Teamfights, and knowing when/where to be when things get tough). 

I've seen alot of high tier players who sped past Bronze and silver into high gold who honestly.. are worse than some bronze IV's I've seen. THey know how to farm fast with an OP champ and just force the game to end in a win, but when it comes to getting put up against players who can do the same, they fail miserably at knowing when/where and how to properly team fight, and be productive. Do these people still deserve that tier? I don't believe they do because they fail at all the skills that truly matter. 

It reminds me of games where I have poor cs and a person who has 4x the amount as me keeps bitching, whining and complaining and over all flaming me that I suck because of it, but when push comes to shove, I'm 3x more worthwhile in a team fight than they were/are because I know where to be, what to do, how and when to focus, and consider high priority targets, and any of the other 100 things that could potentially need to be calculated in a team fight. 

However, since that said person me as an example (not saying its how I am) can't carry or master 10000000 cs a game, have a much harder, if not nearly impossible time climbing the ranks. 

Over all the rank system is broken, and really doesn't truly show where anyone 'deserves" to be. It gets close.. but at the same time, still so wrong.

> [{quoted}](name=xMistressAthenax,realm=NA,application-id=cIfEodbz,discussion-id=M3TAHwua,comment-id=000b00040000,timestamp=2014-12-15T00:30:36.641+0000)
> The problem is, where do you draw the line of "you're now where you belong"? What if it takes roughly 6 years to properly even out the 8/10 times getting a leaver/afker to get you where you belong, but nobody knows that.. 3 years down the road everyones telling this silver he belongs there when in reality he belongs in high gold or better? 

It's reasonable to assume that if you're remaining in some rank for any length of time without notable movement in one direction or the other, you're *pretty close* to where you should be. 

> How about those very good players who, just get horrendous teams all the time but don't have the time to sink hundreds of hours a week into league? They'll realistically never get close to seeing the rank they deserve. 

I disagree. I think you're drastically overestimating the amount of time it takes for that normalization to occur, at least in the average case. There may always be outliers, but over time enough the odds of a player *being* an outlier become vanishingly small. After long enough, it becomes statistically impossible (as the odds of it happening exceed the number of unique players). Saw someone do some math on it once, and I think you'd be surprised at how quickly that time approaches.
 
> Obviously the above with the 6yrs is an inflated example, but the point remains. Not everyone gets the same amount of afkers/trolls. Not everyone can carry, but just because you can carry doesn't mean you're a good player either (this is actually true, as just being able to gobble up a crap ton of cs and run everyone through with an OP champ doesn't mean you're good when it comes to real things that matter such as Teamfights, and knowing when/where to be when things get tough). 

There's a lot of various skills required to be "good" at League. Map awareness, mechanical skill, coordination, organization, positioning, farming, and tactical decision-making, to name a handful off the top of my head.

Generally speaking, as players progress up the ranks, they become better and better at more and more of those. But the ranking system views them in aggregate, not individually. A player who's got masterful mechanics and farming skill may not have the wide array of general skills that another player has, but that doesn't mean he deserves his ranking any less. His *overall* skill may be high because of the ridiculous strengths of those two skills.

There's simply no fair way to measure all of those skills that doesn't warp gameplay. I've been watching people propose all kinds of ideas for adjusting LP/MMR gains, for a couple years now, and I have yet to see anything that comes remotely close to accounting for all of the various skills that lead to wins. Except, y'know, measuring win ratio.

It's true that trolls, afks, ragers, and the like tend to warp rankings. But honestly? It really isn't much. And I strongly believe that it's mostly a function of *time*. Like I said, trolls might keep you down a division or two, but they won't keep you there forever, if your actual skill indicates you should be ranked higher.

If you are in bronze, you deserve to be in it. If I were in bronze, I would deserve to be in it. I'm not saying it to be a dick. There aren't as many "outside forces" that keep you in bronze as people try and say. It's this attitude that leads to toxicity in the community. It's the "it's not my fault that I got caught out, my teammates just suck" attitude that leads to toxicity. This should not ever be tolerated. I don't care if your teammates are bad. Everyone gets teammates who need work. This does not give you a reason to shit on their life just because they are bad at the game. I must also remind you that everyone has bad days. You can't be perfect every single game. Everyone makes mistakes. Ease off. I'm not implying that it is necessarily bad to be in bronze at all. Now I know there are people in this community that only have fun by trolling in games, and making it impossible to win. I understand the frustration. But fighting fire with fire will never help. Screaming at them, and whatever else won't help your situation. All you have to do is ignore them. The reason they troll in games is because they can get a rise out of people. So don't give them that opportunity. If they start talking to you in chat, and it annoys you, mute them. Simple. There will always be trolls, it's something that cannot ever be fixed. Some people are just assholes. The more people that ignore the trolls and make them lose at their own game, the less trolls there will be in the long run. If they don't have any fun doing it, they will stop.
